Froment began his work as a school-master. The truths which he taught the children at school, they repeated at their homes. Soon the parents came to hear the Bible explained, until the school-room was filled with attentive 
233
listeners. New Testaments and tracts were freely distributed, and they reached many who dared not come openly to listen to the new doctrines. After a time this laborer also was forced to flee; but the truths he taught had taken hold upon the minds of the people. The Reformation had been  planted, and it continued to strengthen and extend. The preachers returned, and through their labors the Protestant worship was finally established in Geneva.
